comment._content:
John Bruce Bolitho was confirmed as a Second Lieutenant in 3rd Battalion Devonshire Regiment, having served a period on probation, on 12th May 1911.  He was first promoted to Lieutenant on 18th November 1911 [LG 15 Dec 1911].  In February 1912 he was seconded from 3rd Devonshires to the Army Service Corps.

He was again promoted from Second Lieutenant to Lieutenant in the Devonshire Regiment on 3rd May 1915 [LG 27 Jul 1915].

Lieutenant John B Bolitho was 'seconded' from Regimental Duty as an Assistant Equipment Officer on 5th September 1915 [LG of 2 Oct 1915]; he was restored to the Establishment of the Devonshire Regiment on 17th January 1916 [LG of 10 May 1918].

He was promoted to Temporary Captain on 7th February 1916 [LG of 11 Apr 1916].  On 17th February 1916 he was seconded from The Devonshire Regiment for duty with the Army Signal Service [LG of 30 March 1920].

Captain John B. Bolitho Royal Corps of Signals retired from the Army on 16th September 1923. [LG 28 Sep 1923].//

comment.author: 77788549@N05
comment._content:
John Bruce Bolitho was born on 28th November 1889.  He was the son of Captain Edward Alverne Bolitho and Catharine Johns Bolitho nee Bolitho.  He was educated at Wellington College and then Birmingham University.

After the Great War he added the Christian Name Richard, becoming Richard John Bruce Bolitho.  On 14th July 1916 he married Roselle Lampriere and they had three children, Michael Lempriere Bolitho b. 19 July 1917; William Robins Bolitho b. 24 February 1920; and Loveday Roselle Clementine Bolitho, b. 10 October 1923.  

Sadly Michael Lempriere Bolitho, his eldest son, was killed in action on 8th November 1942 at Oran in Algeria whilst serving as a Captain in the Coldstream Guards, aged 25.

In 1965 Richard John Bruce Bolitho was resident at Rosel Manor, Jersey, Channel Islands.

comment.author: 78785369@N06
comment._content: John Bruce Bolitho entered the Army through the Devon Militia in 1910.  He served in France and Flanders with the Devonshire Regiment; the Royal Flying Corps and the Army Signal Service.  In 1918 he was a Captain and Experimental Officer at the Signals Experimental Establishment at Woolwich.  In the Second World War he was Seconded to the Royal Navy 1942-46.  He died in 1965 aged 75.

comment._content: Might not be the same man, but given his area of expertise, signals intelligence and interception, this might be the Captain Bolitho who was employed at Broadway Buildings in 1939-40 under the supervision of MI8 to intercept and decrypt the German military call-sign system. comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Bolitho is A Cornish name. The Bolitho family's growth to prominence started with Thomas Bolitho (1765–1868), great-grandfather of John Bruce Bolitho. The family were initially tanners, who moved into lime-burning and tin smelting before becoming bankers. Their Bank eventually merged with Barclays in 1905. Captain Edward Alverne Bolitho's firstborn was Lt.-Col. Sir Edward Hoblyn Warren Bolitho KBE (1882-1969). He was a landowner and a Lord Lieutenant of Cornwall. Peerage.com gives family info here www.thepeerage.com/p53416.htm#i534159 John Bruce was the 7th of Captain Edward Alverne Bolitho's 12 children. An early aviator - 2nd Lieut. John Bruce Bolitho (Devonshire Regiment) (Bristol Biplane, Bristol School, Salisbury Plain) received Aviators Certificate #762 April 15, 1914. A 30 May 1921 photograph of a very slim Captain Richard John Bruce Bolitho in full Dress uniform, Captain, Devonshire Regiment is found here lafayette.org.uk/bol6453.html "Originator of the whip antenna on tanks in WW1 and held several patents for radio improvements. He also originated, and recruited staff by unorthodox means, for some of the initial work at Bletchley Park." As of 11 March 1932 changed his name by deed poll to Richard John Bruce Bolitho - of Ponsandane, Penzance, in the county of Cornwall, and St.Martins, in the island of Jersey ... (London Gazette)
